5qZXrBaE67G-sUeoGZkAPw.text: I had a bite to eat ( to call it a meal  would be entirely inaccurate) on 10.05.12 with 2 others.  We were told upon entering taht we would have no more than 90 minutes at the table - I rather wish that they had told us to clear off and saved us a heap of frustration.We ordered 3 starters, 4 small dishes and three mains (1 Seafood curry and 2 steaks)  The food was cooked exceptionally well (the only saving grace of the evening) but at £6 odd for for a quarter of an avocado with sauce and similar prices for a bowl of Edamame or 4 slices of raw beef we are talking about fine dining with Michelin stars here.  The service was appallingly lacking.  To have the dishes arrive ad hoc in any order and just be dumped on the table somewhat like school diners is far from acceptable.  I had received my main dish before some of the starters and the small dishes which arrived as and when.  We persevered.  We finished our starters and side dishes and my main but the two steaks had yet to arrive. We used the interactive display to call for a waiter to ask why they hadn't delivered two mains 40 minutes after we had ordered but were told that sorry but the steak had run out (he said that he would remove them form our bill, jolly decent of him really). Resignedly my companions ordered small dishes of duck and pork ribsThe duck arrived 10 minutes later and was eaten but still no sign of the ribs.10 minutes later we cancelled the ribs and asked for the bill but the ribs arrivedWe received the bill and removed the optional service charge from the bill.  Asked why I explained that the service was all over the place and appalling and the woman taking the money did not seem surprised at all.DON'T GO HEREWagamamas is not very good but but a damn site better than this place and they make no pretense that it is anything other than slam it down fast food and get the customers out quick so that they get more bums on seats.I must be getting old - I want to enjoy my meal rather than cram it down and run which seems to be the view of InamoJust checked a review from 9/9/10 that raves about Chef Cam etc, piss poor CCTV pics don't cut it for me.Whoops i should have checked here first - just read the other reviews and they are all pretty damning, trouble is I never believe the reviews until I have tried the venues for myself and my leaving this review is only a way of venting my frustrations - aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaarrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrgg­ggggggggggggghhhAt the end of this review is a poke panel multiple choice for other bits likeGood For:    Dessert    Late Night    Lunch    Dinner    Breakfast    Brunchand you can tick any but YELP you forgot to put the option    Nothing

Os0CmTHFhp_a24TEiIJFBg.text: Echoing lots of what has already been written.. Very cool setup and atmosphere. The interactive tables making it unique. The food is good, but not mind-blowing in any way, but worth a visit for the atmosphere alone. :)

UtFzsfI8_ONhwruX0TD4uA.text: Inamo, Soho is absolutely fantastic. It's a geeks paradise and i'd highly recommend it. Best bits: - Incredible computer display for ordering food, changing the theme of your table, "chef cam", ordering a cab and much more. - Great food. Asian fusion - try the spicy spare ribs! - Friendly staff (you don't see much of them, but when you do, they're very nice) - Great location - Right bang in the middle of Soho. This isn't just a nerds paradise, it's a great spot for young/old + locals/visitors.

M24-1ucX-6J3MNW3e1Cnuw.text: I'd first heard of Inamo just before it opened, when I was sent a film clip outlining its interactive table concept. Then a few weeks ago, I tried it for myself. There were four of us in the group and as we hadn't reserved, we were sent to the basement bar to have a cocktail while we waited. A complimentary plate of snacks was served to us at the same time - with edamame beans and other Oriental snacks. Our waiter was incredibly friendly and we didn't mind waiting at all. The basement was pretty quiet when we were there but I can imagine it would be heaving on a Friday night. When we were taken to our table upstairs, conversation quickly stalled as our waiter gave us a quick demonstration of how to order via the touch-sensitive pad on the table, and then we started to play - with the menu, with the taxi ordering service, with the various different options on the table. Once we'd all ordered a variety from the Asiatic menu. we started to play battleships in our two respective pairs. I definitely wouldn't consider Inamo cheap, but the food is good and for the geek in us the interactive tables are fantastic fun. I think it's a great concept that we'll probably see popping up in different establishments before too long, but the thing that really won me over was being able to thrash my friend at battleships. Now, that was fun.

-9Tvbr4h4fvJ7wFovImw_Q.text: Great idea, food is really nice, the korean chicken was sooooo sooo good and the fish great quality. Very quick to bring out the food. Although I agree that it is a bit over priced and that the staff are a bit too cool for school. The whole booking system on their website is a bit over the top. We went on a sat for lunch, and the place was empty, yet the booking system made me feel like I was booking somewhere like 'The Fat duck'. They need to come down off their home made pedestal and get back to what they set out to do, fun, innovative way of eating great food!

qR5gv0Mr0qhCsbRFWgECGQ.text: I am still wondering how come this place is not rated with 5 stars?? I made a reservation for my boyfriends birthday. I didnt know if they did any birthday desserts so i sent an email. Aside from the fact that their online reservation system rocks, their answer was ALMOST immediate, by 1 min!!! We got to the place, they sat us, and we were amazed by the fact that you can order with your table, with a tactile mouse on the table you hover over the menu projected on it and you choose anything you want. You can pay games, see food with descriptions and in detail, call the waiter and pay your bill. You can even change the "screen" of your table with different themes!!It was an awesome experience and they have a waiter that sings in a very funny way, so we were the happiest customers ever. Oh and the food was just delicious, we had never eaten such good suchi, duck and ribs in our lifes! Defenitely worth the price (make note: it is a bit pricy, but you get lots of food!)REcommended, 5 stars and most definitely going back!

cwYFV4QALSg-OuUd10FOCA.text: I went to Inamo on a bit of a whim last night as my friend and I just wanted to get out of the rain. I'd been before, but it was her first time and it took her a while to work out the table wasn't like an iPhone...you have to use the little mouse pad! I love the concept of this place - interactive tables and games while you wait. It's a geeks dream. Perfect for first dates if you're feeling awkward and group meals because you get a total for just your food on your table. Can't say fairer than that. I ordered the chicken betal leaf for starters, black cod as a main with sides of greens and rice plus a glass of wine. My total was £33 which feels quite expensive, but I finished full and the food is definitely worth it. Some people have said that the waiting staff aren't very attentive, but I'd say they were pretty good last night. I had a quibble about my black cod which for £15 was significantly smaller than my friends piece - and I'm a stickler for fairness in portion sizes. I complained to the manager and he brought out another piece of cod to share between us and make up for it. He handled it really well and made me feel like he was glad I brought it to his attention so he could help me. I wish all waiters were that good! Go...you'll love it and you'll tell your friends too. But expect to pay around £35 for your meal.

NNxReyOTroyiEmGf_CKfXw.text: Inamo could be the future of eating, or it could be a complete a complete waste of time, like Windows Vista or Baby Toupees (yes, they do exist bit.ly/3qrLMN ). Luckily, whether you love or hate the innovative ordering system, the food is excellent. Was highly impressed by my set lunch menu, which started with a tasty miso soup and was followed up with some delicious cinnamon chicken. Personally I'm not so sure about the concept. The tables work really well, and although gimmicky they do make browsing and ordering food a breeze. The real problem is, like TV's in a pub, the tables end up distracting fellow diners, combine this with the less than personal service a computer provides - and the whole experience feels somewhat lacking.

ve0UgPcEX1Ge-uTcqUCUZA.text: I can't tell you about the food, because I only came here to go to the bar downstairs, but I have heard great things about it from friends who'd just dined there. I do like the design, it's understated yet funky, with mirrors on the walls doubling as both wallpaper and lighting - if that sounds confusing you'll probably have to go yourself to see what I mean - but don't stare for too long, it can send you crazy. We had table service and somewhat efficient waiting, a little slow and she didn't have 2 of the wine choices we ordered but she gave us a decent replacement. We had some great finger food finished with a fiery cocktail that sent me over the edge -  it had a red chili in it. All in all it was around £30 each for plentiful food and 3 or 4 drinks.

eYOTFbTAgE2aO9F7up-EWQ.text: Fusion  Noun -1- Something new created by a mixture of qualities, ideas, or things.2- A style of cooking that combines ingredients and techniques from different cultures or countries. Since September 2008, the word fusion has found a new home at Inamo, a pan-Asian restaurant and bar. Illustrating the perfect fusion of the IT world's ingenuity with the creativity of the chefs' toque, Inamo is a unique concept where customers take control of their own dinner in a sci-fi dinner room experience. The story began five years ago when two young and ambitious students, fed up of waiting for their orders, decided to work on a concept where people would enjoy their meal at their own speed without depending on a waiter's availability and other customer's. Two worlds were about to merge with to attain one objective: Put the means to make each customer's dinner experience exactly what they want it to be at the tips of their fingers, literally. Mouse pads replace the paper menu to order what you want and when you want, get your bill whenever you like, even call a waiter with just the touch of a button. The lamps above your head have metamorphosed into projectors and your table is converted into an interactive tableau where you set your own ambience and design by choosing among different graphics and colours. And if your dearest love is in a challenging mood while waiting to be served, let see how you manage a game of 'battleship'. The home of technological fusion with a dining experience, Inamo could only do itself justice by serving Asian-fusion food; a combination of Japanese, Thai and Chinese cuisine. Countries of technology and innovation, this kind of cuisine finds its place among what looks like at the first glance another gadget. Nine out of ten customers come to Inamo to play with the system, expecting it to be a gimmick but then, they realize that the food is good, explains Mark Eggebrry, general manager at Inamo. We have noticed that by having access to the pictures of the dishes, people select their meal by taste instead of food orientation. Mark's choice to move from the luxury hotel, Sanderson, to Inamo was like asking a kid to design his dream game: When I was first approached about Inamo I must say I was a little bit skeptical. I interviewed with the owners four times before I saw the actual system at work and at that stage I was sold. The possibilities in my mind for this system are endless and I wanted to be a part of this very ground breaking technology and this very unique style of service. If you fancy a unique experience, step into Inamo and you wouldn't be disappointed. The food is diverse and tasty (And the 3-plate chocolate dessert to die for!), the waiters always available to help you and of course, you have a lot of fun playing with your interactive table. One advice though: order your main dish once you've finished with your starter as the team in the kitchen seem to be the most efficient cooks in London. Inamo is definitely a place to go with your friends, your geek husband or a date you want to impress.But if you're looking for a restaurant to celebrate your 25th wedding anniversary with candles and roses, you may want to come back later, unless, of course, your dearest love would appreciate a bouquet of roses as the background of her table. It's all about fusion. Mathilde's Cuisine: What is your relationship to technology?Mark Eggebrry: Personally I love everything about it, I love the fact that I can have my whole life on one device that I can use to organise and work. I just want more, everything easier thanks to technology! How do you define cooking?Cooking for me represents family and friends, coming together for an experience and each others' company. The time taken and effort put into a dish or a meal defines for me how much care was taken to prepare it. What are your influences in cooking?Most certainly for me the biggest influence is Asian cuisine, I have spent most of my career working with Asian foo and, for that very reason, I am very impressed, intrigued and inspired by the ingredients used and how they are combined to give a remarkable end product. What is your favourite sneaky snack?Off our menu I would have to say my favourite snacks are the Pork ribs and the Duck. At home, however, I am less picky and will often sit down to a bag of biltong, (South African dried beef) which I make myself! What is the last cookbook you've read?The most recent one I tried anything from (with marginal success) was Alain Ducasse, however I more frequently use a Jamie Oliver at home book, lots of easy recipes.

SyQn4jIM3Ay1NLvpsbmj1g.text: I would definitely recommend this restaurant if you're after a dining experience with a difference.  It's a great place for lovers of Sushi, but even if you're not a huge fan - the place is great for an evening out with friends or even a date.  The atmosphere is cool and buzzing and kind of reminds me of the bars in NYC.  The touch screen menus on the tables are great fun and make this place really different.  The cocktails are excellent too.

ricePGujoodAkXW8eeEiwQ.text: I've been umming and aahing about what to say on this restaurant as the food was outstanding, but the service was shocking. If there was a 0.5 of a star, believe me I'd use it! The Wagyu beef was velvetine melt in your mouth goodness, the spoonfuls of tuna, ornate creations of delight and the sake warming yet fuzzy. That's where the trouble started, as our initially friendly waiter offered us 'complimentary' sake, which I took to mean 'on the house'. Next up the main food selection, as they were plating up my two friends were informed their food was not available, which was more than irritating considering everyone else was eager to dive in. When my friend said she was cross, the waiter jumped ship and hissy fitted off. The mountain of sashimi offered little respite as we were ushered to leave with an inaccurately calculated bill, that included a more expensive sake to the one dubbed 'on the house'. Such a pity, as the quality of food was conceptual, elaborate and totally 'devoursome'.

gwDNcp4ndEdWiUhyAR7fFA.text: Hands down one of the coolest restaurants I've ever been to, if for no other reason than the sheer coolness factor of it. You walk in and notice that every single table top has a different backdrop that is projected down from a projector above the table. Forget table cloths, that's so 2000. You sit down but no one comes to greet you. No, it's not bad service, it's intended. Inamo has little touchpads on all of its tables that patrons can use to order directly from the kitchen via a menu that is... you guessed it... projected from above. You place your finger on the touchpad and a menu pops up that lets you order everything from drinks to dessert to the bill. Even cooler is the fact that the projector shows you a picture of the food you're contemplating on the plate right in front of you, so you can drool at the presentation. Once you've ordered, you can take a peek at your food being prepped in the kitchen via the video feed and then someone hustles out to put it in front of you. How's that for efficiency? No more waiting for the waiter to come w/ water, or feeling guilty about summoning your server... it's mandatory! No more small talk either, which is also a plus. As for food, it's all quite nice. A blend of Japanese and Thai, they have some fantastic dishes here. Try the Cinnamon Chicken, Yellowtail Hamachi, and Beef Salad, all of which are particularly savory and memorable. Sweet decor, gimmicky ordering methodology, and delicious food make this place a fantastic spot for a date or large group. And while I'm not sure if the have karaoke, from the looks of the place, they should! When are you opening in the US, Inamo?

-Jx5nn8rq4Ni9CH0JynsKA.text: The whole hi tech thing has a certain novelty value but I don't see it being something you'd return to this restaurant for unless you have young children who might enjoy it. The food was distinctly average and quite disappointing for what we paid. It seems as if the food was barely an afterthought. They have to realise that people go to restaurants to eat good food and that computer games alone aren't enough to bring paying customers back through the door.

54PXB8md57aLjo-G6-csmw.text: Very cool concept. I won't repeat the description that another reviewer left, but I certainly did find it "different" to have the menu projected onto the table and use a touch-pad to scroll through the dishes and ultimately place the order. Although it was a bit difficult to get used to not seeing the entire list of available dishes all at once, once we've gone through the list a few times it was easy to order. The technology aspect aside, I think it was quite relaxing and convenient to just order the dishes one at a time as the evening went on. No need to look for a waiter or ask for the menu again. really easy and very conducive to a long conversation :) The food was great. Black cod is definitely the dish to try. Cocktails, however, were all too sweet (and we had our share!) and when we switched to sake, we found the selection a bit small and the 2 choices we went for weren't so great. The good news is that the Long Bar, at the Sanderson Hotel, was just a few blocks away :)

K0QgAm6sS7ClSLxj31WYCA.text: This is one of our favourite places in town. The automated ordering tables are part of the fun but it's the dishes that we go back for again and again. The pork cheeks with chilli chocolate is simply amazing and dishes that have to be ordered each visit include mushroom toban yaki dish, duck pancakes, soft shell crab maki roll and sashimi platter...Yum. And yum again.The service is sweet, attentive and helpful and it is great to able to choose to engage with your server or not (and not have time to re think that second bottle of wine!) Feeling anti social or got an awkward date then the tables come into their own.It keeps us coming back, when we're not eating our own lovely tapas that is ; )

Xotl4vqX4LI8jC8VGjHUiw.text: Fabulous meal here - and so much fun! Service was increbily attentive when we needed something and drinks and food were brought promptly and within the quoted time. I had the black cod for my main, which was the perfect blend of sweet and salty, and the salmon avocado ceviche, which was also wonderful (maybe could have used a pinch more salt). Drinks were moderatly priced and food competitively so. I reccomend that if you're looking for a cheap night out, don't order any alcohol.

KaxdzeqAOjASaM0HMXpJsw.text: What is Inamo? Is it a restaurant? Is an experience? Is it any good?Certainly the first of its kind I have ever been to, Inamo doesn't have menus - not paper ones anyway. Overhead projectors illuminate your table (with various table 'cloth' patterns that you can choose) and you use a little scroll pad to select from the digital menu. It's certainly novel and I had fun playing around with the different options but the technology felt slightly dated somehow. Damn you Apple and your multi-touch interfaces! There are certainly possibilities here however. I loved the kitchen webcam, the fact that you can call a taxi automatically when you leave, and it's a perfect application for ordering drinks. Maybe I'm a dying breed (at the ripe old age of 24) but part of going out to dinner is the service and Inamo confidently replaces that aspect with a literally heads down approach. More, half way through my meal I noticed how quiet the restaurant seemed, not in density, but in decibel level - everyone had they're heads down playing on their tables. Inamo has created a social and anti-social environment all at once. The future is now.  Oh right! I nearly forgot, I ate food while there. How could I have left out such an important aspect of my dining experience? This is a restaurant review after all. Maybe because the food was forgettable? Yeah that's gotta be it. Boar rolls were overly chewy but not terrible. Mushroom something something was not memorable (clearly). Inamo tries but way too hard. If they eased up on the sauce, the schtick, and decided who they were, they'd improve greatly. So what is Inamo? Like many tourist attractions, it's worth checking out if you want something you've never seen before. The technology is certainly innovative and it makes you consider why you go out to restaurants in the first place (for good and bad). If you're looking for an experience to share with friends or to see something you haven't before, Inamo is a safe bet. But if you're like me and associate 'restaurant' with food and not technology head elsewhere.

dbaDQRhlKR3mbvScvbY8rg.text: i'm not sure why this restaurant barely has any 5-star review. my experience at inamo was unforgettable - both for the food and design of the place itself.i ordered the sushi assortment for appetizer, the beijing duck as my entree, and the sweet basil panna cotta for dessert. dare i say, the panna cotta might be one of my favorite desserts of all time. and the best part about it was it did not leave you wanting more, as it was a good size which fills up any hunger left over after the entree.the concept behind the interactive table is genius - i think. my parents, never having played battleship before, enjoyed losing to my siblings, which in turn i found pleasure in seeing.the soft-spoken, cool manager gave us almost a 50% discount off our bill after my dad mentioned that the restaurant was closed when he made a reservation for dinner on christmas. the manager's quite dreamy, might i add.i definitely love the vibe of the place too. if i lived in london, this is a place i would definitely love to go to on a date.

u3KB1A-QexvWXmFzLd4JdQ.text: I rarely give anything 5 stars but Inamo on my first vist was fantastic. Like most people perhaps I wasn't expecting outstanding food as I was more drawn to the technology and 'gimmicky' hype of the restaurant. However everything I ordered tasted great, the entire experience was effortless and the food was excellent. To top it all my desert was just heaven, lovely pistaccho cream with great little detailsimpressive. My only gripe with Inamo is that I cannot seem to get another booking, they're always busy!!

m45OGpm6pSYH7lvEOLemXw.text: Went there for birthday this weekend. Booked on the same day via opentable and various times were available. The call to confirm reservations and ensure you understand when you need to vacate your table (remind you again when you arrive). Surprisingly it wasn't full and there were lots of empty tables. Could be because I was there early though. The price of food is quite high but I suppose this is paying for the novelty of the interactive table. I liked ordering on the table as food cameout quite quickly. The pre theatre menu between 3:30pm -6:30pm was very affordable. I paid £10 for a good diverse platter of ribs , miso soup, pickles, rice, tempura. The ribs were good and tasty (flavorful bbq). The appetizers that accompanied the ribs was nice but nothing special. I also had the marble beef (carpaccio) and that was exceptionally flavorful and had many dimensions of taste- sweet,salt- as well as texture. Overall I would come back again but only to introduce friends to the novelty of the restaurant. Would recommend to try at least once.

6TPxQ1jzsXm5LdHE9HPBng.text: When I got there, I was thinking this place was somewhere between four and five stars.  By the time I left it was verging on two.I really like the concept of the place.  Yes, it's a gimick.  Yes, it would get very tired if you were a regular, but it's surely not the kind of place that you would be a regular at surely?  And what saves it is that the food is really good.  Admittedly my edamame were overcooked, but everything else was great - I am still thinking about the tuna in bean curd, but there were lots of great dishes, washed down by a really interesting cocktail (the one with chilli and spring onions - definitely try it if you're into interesting taste combinations).The computer/projection system is slick, and full of nice touches.  It's a good place for a first date because if you run out of conversation you can always play battleships.So, why did it plunge in my opinion.  The earliest reservation we could get was 8.45 - fine, we could get a few beers first and it's open until half eleven.  Cue 9.25pm and we're asked to place any last orders.  We'd only just ordered out first batch of food.  I was not happy.Then they did that incredibly rude thing of really visibly clearing up around you.  Then they started spraying and wiping down the tables next to us!  There is not better way in the world to make me want to camp out in your restaurant.  I mean, come on, this isn't the cheapest restaurant in London (I see from their website that you have to pay £150 just to get a table on Valentine's Day) - you can at least have the manners to let us eat a meal in peace.No tips for them then.  But it gets back up to three stars just on the memory of the tuna and the spring onion cocktail.

RvEIgBEeI_Xvs9f7HUN5Uw.text: The service here was by far some of the greatest I have received in London. The staff was there as soon as you pressed the button on the table. It was very cool and interactive.The food here was good when it was served fresh. The black cod was delicious and easily my favorite. I agree with other Yelpers it was great! Tried a couple of the rolls and the appetizers. Nothing else was quite as good. The Inamo drink was a but spicy and hard to drink. Literally hard to swallow at times. Be weary of this peppery treat.The games on table were fun and battleship was the crowd favorite. Try this cool interactive experience but don't know how often I'll be returning. Felt rushed as I was not the only one that wanted to play with this cool environment.

3NqZ9VoP3WvkRpQt-W_Xtw.text: Awesome concept!!!  Love the interactive table and menu.  Huge pluses with features like the chef cam, games, and it even has a map so you can plan on where you want to go after dinner.  Minus one star for the unfriendly host and the strict 1.5 hour restriction on your reservation. What we had:-Passion fruit martinee:  Yum!!!  -Mojito:  tasty, but not as good as the passion fruit martinee.-Cod:  The BEST thing we ordered that night... It was juicy, flakey fish that had a perfect balance of sweetness-hot stone rib-eye:  the ribeye came out the perfect medium rare... I should have taken the meat off because by the time i got to the second slice, it was well done.  It came with 3 sauces... Couldnt really hear the waiter name the sauces since it was really loud in there. - Spicy Thai beef salad:  This was really good.. with the perfect amount of spicyness- crab roll:  YUCK.. it was dry and flavorless... Dont order thisAll in all, it was a great experience... =)

6fBf3t192DO2_GDHTsf_EA.text: Ordering through the tables is a great gimmick, and I'm surprised other restaurants haven't copied the concept.For me it's great that the quality of the of the food isn't overshadowed by the novelty of the ordering system. The prices per dish are about average for Soho, but the portion sizes are quite small so you find yourself ordering double.The choice of drinks is pretty good and you can even try the intriguing mandarin and chili martini.I've been to Inamo a few times now and the menu seems to change, albeit subtly, a few times a year.My only gripe is that they've taken coffee off the dessert menu!

PYNQ-27oAWcCdb-7EycggA.text: This place is a total geekfest! I have been here twice and both times I went with people who love tech-stuff. Using a touchpad, you select everything from your food/drink order to the ambiance projected on your table. You can play battleship with your partner, watch the chef cam, and even have a taxi called for you - all at your table by selecting with your mouse. So it's totally fun.The food is tasty and I was happy with the quality of it, but it does get pricey very quickly.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

YE_8LdBBYnzF17jOCAr9kQ.text: Too gimmicky for my taste. Plus, pretentious hostess who says their restaurant is all booked when there are only 10 guests at 5:30pm on a Sunday. Not a fan of this place. Still looking for a legit sushi place in London....

nz1F-E6C4ILfMpUFw-KzzQ.text: While it's easy to be WOWED by their touch screen tables (which everyone wants to use like an iPhone, but is then terribly disappointed by the limitations of the "touch screen") I'm not so impressed with this place.While their cocktails are pretty good and their selection of pan-Asian cuisine is quite diverse, I feel like they try too hard. Their menu doesn't change as often as somewhere like Ping Pong Dim Sum does, and while I do like the Tempura Vegetable dish, it gets old very quickly.Their spring rolls are good, but not great. Their rice is OK. Their sushi is fancy but not the best...Their staff is smiley, but not friendly. It's just "OK"... or more like the posh version of "Meh".I appreciate being able to order food in my own time and like that I can change up the light display on my table - but to be honest, if I'm going to go out with a group of friends, I like to just have things be a bit more old fashioned, and the food, well, better.If you're adventurous and are in need of a new dining experience, this place is cool. But again, after visiting this place more than once for both dinner and lunch, I feel like Ping Pong is more fun, and has much tastier food.

1EWySF6BkId7fRASBuwc0A.text: If you fancy a different dining experience this is the place to go. The concept behind this restaurant is really great because it adds an element of fun and surprise to the whole choosing and ordering experience. Still, if you find the trackpad system hard to use, the staff are really friendly and eager to explain/help. It's all very carefully thought out.The food comes Asian-style - it arrives when it's ready, meaning it's cooked fresh, and it's meant to be shared. I went with vegetarian people and the choice was good. It's also great for a late night snack,which might be your only option unless you reserve a table well ahead !

uNJjTVJl-eVXsDqwH0HH9g.text: If you have never heard of Inamo then you don't watch the Gadget show LOL.They have a fully interactive service where you order your own food and drinks from the interactive menu that is projected on the table. The restaurant is in the centre of Soho opposite Lee Stafford's salon (Strange the things you take notice of. It is very classy inside. Blacks and whites. It seemed a lot smaller than I was expecting though too. Not many tables and not much room to get around. The toilets are tiny even though there are 2 cubicles in the ladies there is only 1 sink and not enough room for 2 ladies to stand in there. When it comes to ordering it couldn't be easier. You have a little touchpad (as on a laptop) and you move the cursor over the various icons. You can order from a selection of Beers and Wines and as soon as you order your drink, it is practically on your table. You have a choice of many dishes for starters and main dishes. Thius means that you don't have to wait for the rest of your party you just order when you are ready and the food arrives in about 15 minutes. Other options on the interactive menu are a chef cam where you can see streaming pictures from the kitchens to see them hard at work. To be honest I wonder if this is live or if it is just a looping recording.You can even change the ambience which has a choice of different Wallpapers for your table or you can pick random and it changes every 2 minutes. My problem with it was that it was very sensitive and I am use to clicking too hard so I almost ordered just about everything on the menu and had to keep deleting rogue orders. A WARNING! As with anything that relies on computers we know that Computers can be unreliable. As I was waiting for my food to arrive, A member of staff came and told us that the computers had gone down and therefore the kitchen had stopped coking because the orders weren't getting to them. We asked if they could possibly take the orders with a pad and pencil but they said no and that was that. So it was a shame that some of our party had only had starters which aren't very substantial. Luckily I did get my food - I had ordered the Pomegranate Duck which was worth the wait although it wasn't very warm and I wondered if it was meant to be eaten cold A great experience if the technology is working but they really should have a back up plan.

Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

KsltGMkDiW2jygAJ63Jmbg.text: This funky little place is fine if you want a bit of a gimmick.  The interactive menu is confusing to start with, but we really liked being able to order the bill electronically.  shame the food is merely average.

TSncwpXNupPOsGJaF1cLAQ.text: Wow, I really wish I'd been on a first date here because I really can't think of a better place to go with a new prospective honey.Inamo is a seriously, seriously cool place with fantastic food, brilliant concept and ambience, and the promise of a whole lot of fun.The meal works like this:You're shown to a table (built in to the floor, so they can't be pushed together for a group) and explained the way the table....erm,....works. There's a high-res projector positioned above each table that projects images down on to the table. Each seat has a little mini track-pad which controls the projected icons on the table, icons which allow you to do heeeeeeeella stuff while you dine:--see the menu--change the pattern on the (projected) "table cloth"--play puzzle games--find out about nearby clubs and bars--view "Chef Cam"-- a live camera in the kitchen that allows you to view the chefs preparing the meal--request waiter service (like a call button on an airplane)--order a taxi home. The coolest thing was the menu function; you scroll down through various categories of menus (Starters, Mains, Sides, Beer and Wine, Cocktails, Desserts, etc) and once you select a dish to view, it projects a description of the dish onto the table and a photo-quality image of the dish onto your plate. SO COOL!!! You eventually make your choice and order through the table than with a waiter, and prepare yourself for the awesome.The food was absolutely effing DELICIOUS, by the way. This isn't one of those concept-heavy substance-light sort of joints. As I was dining on an expense account, I splurged on the sashimi starter and the Kobe beef with mushroom. OMIGODSOAMAZING. Like, seriously, brah. The sashimi was fresh and flavourful, and the beef was so fantastically tender with a brilliant little charred crunch around the edge. My colleagues and I shared a couple portions of the crispy steamed vegetables, which were substantially less boring than they sound. A nice glass of Merlot to finish it off and I was one very happy camper.The only (actually quite major) problem with our meal was the method with which it was delivered. As with Wagamama's, they warn diners as they're being seated that meals may not come out at the same time. They neglected, however, to leave let us know to 15-20 minutes between placing the order for our starters and ordering our main courses. Most of our group ordered both items together, and about half of us got our mains before the starters arrived (not like in the wow-that's-speedy way but in the stuff-came-in-the-wrong-order way). Some of us (me included) didn't get our starters until everyone else had finished both courses as well as an after-diner cocktail. It was very weird. If they had explained this one detail to us at the start of the meal, things would much more fluid and this would have been a 100% 5-star dining experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. What else is there to do in Soho? Let's ask the in-table concierge!
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. Kobe Beef at Inamo... NOM NOM NOM
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. CHEF CAM!!! Live webcam in the kitchen, projected onto the table

Kb3m2dS4cCpjMr97K2U5dA.text: Dined recently on a Sunday evening with a friend at Wardour Street site.Waited to get a table, as not reserved, but had to wait for more than 5 mins, for the front of house/reception personto show us to a table downstairs, when even asked straight away, if a table for two was available. She was too busy behind with few things, and did not attend to us immediately. At least, if someone came to us and told us, when a table would be free, or how long we would need to wait.The dishes ordered were kind of average in comparison to the prices. The menu seems to change regularly. Surely as a Japanese/Asian Fusion Restaurant, Green Tea should be shown on the menu. Not sure if there had been a change of Chef, but certainly a few of the dishes did not meet quality and one of the sushi maki order placed, when arrived, looked as if someone pressed with fingers onto the wasabi. Never seen a sushi dish in other places with side wasabi paste half eaten or rubbed along the plate. Not really, what I would call, a high standard. But, I guess every Japanese restaurant is different. Asked one of the waiting staff, on a particular dish in which I have tried previously, that it did not show on the interactive system menu, and the person was not too sure, and said he will ask his manager, but never returned with the answer. Had to ask again to someone else, but a simple question I think takes long at this particular place. Did not request or put in a order, just wanted to find out if the dish was available. The portions of the appetizers are slightly small size, and a few dish presentation has kind of stepped down. Their customer service lacks in terms of the state of the art interactive projection system. Perhaps it was just us, in which service did not meet up to our satisfaction. I think Inamo has gone down the ladder in quality and level of service.Don't be fooled by its hi-tech projection system.Plenty of high standard Japanese, Fusion restaurants in town with real service.

KvHvyuB2-3Tea_lODQP_-w.text: Ever fantasize about being in a futuristic sci-fi film?  Well, here's your chance.  At least for me, eating here felt like I had leaped 30 years forward.  Mostly because of the illuminated, touch-sensitive table.  Ordering is done wholly by using the interactive touch interface, with waitstaff preferring to take a decidedly hands-off approach.  My waitress, if you'd call her that, only stepped in at the absolute minimally required times.  Perhaps this isn't for the traditional types, who'd like to ask the waiter for recommendations, for example.  Some people may also find the illuminated tables distracting and find the urge to play with it overrides conversation, at least initially.  The dishes I had were heavily Thai influenced.  Prices seemed to be on the high-end, especially considering the smaller-than-usual portions.  However the dishes I had were somewhat tasty and unusual.  Overall, I think this place is a must-try for an unforgettable night.  Perhaps less for the food, and more for the ultra high-tech dining experience.

ixHQRHbrYSg9aHRh--1Fiw.text: Woweeeeee!  The black cod here is amazing.... Inamo is a fun place to go if you fancy a dining experience with a twist.  The computer projections on the tables allow you to order your food and drinks and request the bill without having to talk to the waiters. You can also play games and change the image being projected onto your table.  This place would be great for a first date, because if it turns out that you are not really into your date, you can totally ignore them and play computer puzzle games on the table instead...ha!The service was prompt and the food was good.  I got a bento box for around £25, which had mixed sashimi, tofu, miso soup, edamame, black cod and rice. It was tasty - and again, I have to say: GET THE BLACK COD! Sooooo yummy!It's a little pricey here, but not too bad, and certainly not much more than most other Japanese restaurants in London.You definitely need to book in advance as it gets very busy!

t3J1PjcfOhCDFsVws66VJw.text: LOVED this place. It was the coolest restaurant. The concept is so clever with the little computers on each table. I've gotta say, it's the first time I've ever been able to play battleship at dinner. If you like mushrooms, the vegetarian mushroom main course is fabulous. I'm for sure going back and ordering the same thing. The drinks were amazing! All sorts of fun cocktails (passionfruit martini!) to try. Definitely would recommend this place.

eUCw_aSUWkvsCGUVpdolZw.text: I went to Inamo a couple of weeks ago and am already looking for an excuse to go again. Oh my goodness it.was.so.good! We had some scallops, pork but my favorite was some sea bass sashimi that had a tea dipping sauce and it was clean and divine. I also had a very lovely flowering tea that came in a rather ornate tea pot and it complimented my meal perfectly. The food here isn't cheap but the ways in which you can play games on the table as well as change the background if you so wish is pretty cool. I also like that you can order things when you want so that you don't feel under pressure to have all your food decisions done by the time the waiter gets back or tries to upsell something or other. My only slight agitation is that they are quite strict on how long you have at a table. They aren't flexible and they will chase you out of the restaurant as your minute is up. Still, its a great idea, the quality of food is fantastic and they make cocktails to die for. Go for the experience and is a definite great place to go if you want to impress on a first date. But I would say its definitely a place to go when feeling flush.

l7L0_xKlnHacXArMdp8Fzg.text: OK here's the thing. This is how Tom Cruise ordered his food in the deleted scenes from "Minority Report." I was visiting London and my friend/hostess took me here, telling me I'd be fascinated by the ordering process. And I was!I think it's a shrewd move on the restaurant's part, because ordering is such a fun experience you're apt to do it as often as you can; therefore, you end up spending more than you probably would. I had fun just playing with the different wallpapers. Then again, I can be like a kid sometimes.The food? The food was delicious. We ordered a number of different dishes to provide a good sampling. Every one of them was absolutely delicious.Definitely book ahead. We did for pre-theatre on a Friday night and almost didn't get in. But I'm glad we did - it was worth the experience, and I'd definitely go back.

0t_EVLXVNEJAohwAO9SjDQ.text: The problem I have with Inamo is that whilst the food is good, the concept of being able to order on a virtual menu projected onto your table detracts from the experience of being in a restaurant as it's very impersonal. I also think the food is slightly overpriced and you need quite a few dishes to feel full. i probably wouldn't go back unless i was entertaining a client.

v_lGPhHZzwnAF2IU5OqAbw.text: Very cool place. The most interesting stuff - interactive tables of coarse. The food is good as well. Will take my friends or parents if they come to London - it's like a tourist attraction!

EK_neFpfcYcK5RfWhf5w1Q.text: what a cool place to eat, not just the food was delicious, the projector menu was quite created, too. Really nice food! highly recommended !

OHPejGzgn4sPUE7nqC-sPQ.text: This is a place ive walked by countless times. My friend told me about the concept and it sounded awesome. One bipolar weather afternoon, my friend and i walked by, and as it started to rain, we decided to pop in.. The Food, was lovely. Obviously made with love and care, with well balanced flavours and elegant presentation. The service?  Well, your "waiter" is the cool technology that they use. The menu is projected onto the table and you have a a little touch pad that you order from. It also gives you fun little games, like battleship, that you can play against your dining partner. The human waiters themselves didnt really do much. They barely bring over the dish, dump it on your table and scamper away. When the bill came and we saw a 10% discretionary service charge on there we laughed and didn't pay it. A flaw in their cool gadget thing: you cant order everything at once. You order dish by dish, as you find them on the menu, but then it comes out so staggered that it feels really disjointed. Being as the small plates were first described to us as we sat down as "designed to share," we didnt think it would be too much of a problem, but waiting 5-10 min between dishes when they were only 4-6 bites each was a bit much. The value for money was a bit off. We had this lovely hamachi sashimi with a mirin sauce that was almost £7 and it only came with 4 small slices of fish. um.... yeah.  Not impressed. We spent over £40 and left still hungry. I get it, you pay for the cool technology and the food is good, but i think it would be better suited for a silly dinner spot with friends where you're not noticing the poor service or small portions. They also do a cheap enough set menu, which might be another way to go, or maybe just get a large plate. The small ones, as delicious as they are, just arnt worth it.

7vpsNG3t0J0ya6ov9FaZjw.text: This i is an Asian fusion restaurant with a one-of-a-kind interactive ordering system. Seeing the outside you may think it is just an ordinary restaurant butt looks can be deceiving. The whole experience is something different but I didn't think the food was great, the portions are extremely small for what you pay. And there are a limited choice of drink.

i-Ye1LWGJmBMFyW3cN_rqg.text: What a treat!  My husband, 12 year old son and I went to Inamo tonight before seeing the play "The Mouse Trap".  The staff was fabulous and attentive, and were happy to help explain the interactive table and ordering system when we arrived.  The hostess suggested that each person order two small plates and one main dish to either eat by oneself or to share. We all happily scrolled through the mouse driven system embedded in the table; each "plate" showing up in front of you as to how the actual food would look on the plate, and with a box that described it off to the side.The ordering process was seamless and easy. The food came out looking exactly as it was shown on the interactive system, and it tasted even better!  In between ordering each plate, my husband and son played games, and my son had a great time changing the table background.  There is even an option to "watch the kitchen" live via the kitchen cam so you can see the chefs busy at work preparing the food.We all shared an order of Edamame to start. They were fabulous and were served with a great sauce on the side.  I had small batter dipped shrimp with a sweet/spicy sauce on the side that was to die for as my first small plate, and then a salmon roll for the second. Both were fabulous.  My son and husband both had the chicken satay with spicy peanut dipping sauce that neither could get enough of for their first small plate; my son a dumplings for his second, and my husband grilled cod wrapped in leak for his second.  Both were outstanding.   My salmon for the large plate was amazing; my son had the black cod and was bummed when it was gone, and my husband had pork neck.  None of us could stop raving about how great this restaurant concept and food were!For dessert, we all had creme brule in a raspberry sauce.  It did not disappoint!  My husband and I were each served coffee in our own small french presses. We are here in London for my son's spring break, and told the manager that we would definitely recommend this to any of our friends coming to London, and that we would look forward to coming back!  Don't' miss this restaurant on your next trip!

4lKPFaKWF0a1RKqSLmDX_A.text: Meh.  The interactive table dining is the main attraction of this restaurant while the sushi takes the backseat here. The table interface is pretty entertaining but distracting from the dining experience, esp. when you're trying catch up with friends. The sushi was pretty uninspiring and service was a bit spotty.Call me old-fashioned, but it was pretty annoying not having an attentive wait-staff come to provide suggestions and help with any trouble. It took forever to navigate the menu using the interactive tabletop thing. I would have much preferred a paper menu to order off of, that probably is a blasphemous request at Inamo. Overall, come here for a relatively fun dining experience and play battleship against the person across from you as you eat sushi but don't expect the best sushi in London here. Worth a shot to try out just to say you've done it.

6XfOjQlW3RbTAp1_lHWh-g.text: This was my third visit to Inamo & probably the best of the three. As most people have said it is a geek's paradise to be able to order food from the interactive tables, have a peek into the kitchen through the table's webcam, change the background of the table & play memory games if you're really bored. I think what made this the best visit was the attentiveness of the staff. We had a bit of confusion about the time our table was booked & also arrived early but we were made welcome in the cocktail bar downstairs. We were seated five minutes after our booking time, with many apologies from the receptionist over the confusion (it seriously wasn't a big deal for us) I stupidly ordered my main course about two minutes after my starter, so it meant it was sitting around on the table for a while before my friend's main arrived. One of the waiters kindly noticed this & offered to heat up the food. When our final bill arrived, the two cocktails we had downstairs were the wrong cocktails, they were immediately taken off the bill. We asked about putting the right cocktails back on & the waiter said "No probs have them on the house as you shouldn't have had the wrong ones put on". Who were we to say no to free cocktails ;-) The staff were all extremely friendly & one of the waiters seemed genuinely excited about the opening of their new branch (Regent's Street) in December, giving a great description of what it would look like. The food was very tasty, beautifully presented and yes, as others have said, maybe the main course portions were a tad small for the price, but if you stock up on the delicious Baby ribs and vegetable tamaki beforehand you won't feel hungry. It was my friend's first visit & she was really impressed & can't wait to return with her boyfriend. I'll definitely be back again and looking forward to trying the new branch when it opens!

Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

-CqVSmQtjbMASl-GEiawyg.text: You come here for the experience, not the food. The interactive tables are entertaining for the first 10 minutes, however I found it to be quite an unsocial concept as everyone is staring at their tables for a while until the novelty of it wears off. The food was ok. We had the crab sushi, the tuna sushi, the salmon main and the beef bim bop main. They were all tasty, however I though everything was overpriced for the amount of food and the quality of food served. Good for the experience, however, I wouldn't come here hungry unless you're ready to fork out £50 per person for average food.

oJjFo3sVaxu5R6EhFpNq-Q.text: The interactive tables were cute but not technologically groundbreaking - they have Battleship and you can look through the menu. Our server was super awkward - totally clueless about the food and barely spoke English. We only came here for dessert and a drink to check out the table gimmick. Probably wouldn't recommend it for anything more than a drink, for the novelty of the place.

e2IrksD9Oz5jJppQG55CLQ.text: Really great concept of restaurant and serve really nice food as well. It is the first restaurant in London with new technology on the table. It could not work if the food is bad, but here the food is really good as well.

1Ys_KZ64nNAldX1o2xGSfQ.text: Too expensive and not much choice in the menu. The only fun thing is the table which is interactive! Service is slow and the portions are tiny

K_Qihftip6yo2Tdq3gTW5A.text: Fun interactive menus with games in case you're the first in your party to arrive. Food was good too! We had a mixture of sushi, sashimi and random extras and everything was great - fast too.I would've liked it if someone told us how to use their ordering system, but a few minutes of poking around and we figured out how to order.

isQibQrp6s_UaG2uj3CSlA.text: just came back from this establishment ( I cannot call it a restaurant).... and what a disappointment... the food tastes as it was made in a supermarket and the left overs brought to our table... it has no connection with Japanize cuisine... we paid 80 pounds to try and see an interactive table....

Fi92NpdLnV-JXGDcpM4OXg.text: A very cool concept: interactive table tops. You can toggle through the various menus, see a picture of the meal you're considering and order with a click of a button. Not long after, a server brings your dish. You can change the "wallpaper" of your table and play games while you wait too. Perhaps it's because of the table tops, but the restaurant was really dark. First, we went downstairs to the bar to meet our party for a drink before dinner. There, we were reminded of our "time limit" at for our reservation. Huh? We asked if we could push our reservation back a 1/2 hour so we could have a cocktail. Weird. There wasn't a line of patrons waiting at the door or anything. The cocktail lounge/bar is a little creepy, being so dark. We were kind of prodded by the staff to get to our table. As we ordered and ate, we noticed the room was emptying... no new patrons. My only guess is that they rush you so they can close on time, which seems super important in London. The food was good and the self-ordering was sort of cool, but made me question the tip. Complaint: it's a little distracting and difficult to maintain conversation with this toy around. If you have a techie in your party, he/she may never look up again!Definitely fun for the novelty, but I wouldn't go again.

948mGJH2vk3EurGenuvUEQ.text: Inamo was probably a better idea in concept than in practice. The principal theme to the restaurant is that tables double up as computer screens and that from these you can order your meal, watch the kitchen at work and even book a taxi home. The menu options is visually displayed in front of you and there is the option to set the table colour and design as you would prefer. Although I would agree that this is a clever gimmick and a fun way to order a meal, any more than half an hour in Inamo and the novelty really does wear off. Can you imagine what forty tables all set to their own florescent colour scheme actually looks like? It's only the occasional wine glass and plate of food that separates it from the Christmas light display on Oxford Street. This is a real shame because the food in Inamo is actually of a very high quality. The Black Cod was beautifully presented and melted in the mouth and the Crispy Prawns were effortlessly moreish. Unfortunately even this didn't distract us from our surroundings and we couldn't help but notice the negative effect this 'interactive' restaurant was having on some of the other tables. The couple to my left had stopped any pretence of bothering to talk to each other and were completely transfixed on a game of battleship. Another pair further along had accidentally ordered three bottles of wine at once, failing to understand the touch pad system. I'm sure there are many people that will completely disagree with this review and love all of the technological touches. Personally however, I'm more of a fan of the old fashioned approach. The focus should be on the food and not the environment and I should be able to chat away to my waiter without ringing the virtual bell on my table. If you are nervous about a first date though and conscious that the conversation might wear a bit thin then maybe Inamo is just the place. Maybe just double check there's not history of epilepsy in the family first though...

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

palv0fcOfJDjZ_srrYBfLA.text: THIS is the place to take your date to! The 'interactive tables' are a fantastic idea and fun to use too (means you don't need to communicate with the staff at all-just order your food and drinks and enjoy your companion.) The food is a real treat of contemporary Asian cuisine. I recommend the 'tasting menu for £30' which I shared with my friend. Later we ordered the 'spinach and porcini mushroom parcels' side dish and some 'seared scallops', mmm heavenly combination. On top of that we had a nice bottle of red Merlot wine and baring in mind this restaurant is located in Soho I was pretty surprised by having to pay just 35£ (each)! I can't wait to find another 'special' occasion so that I come back again and againps_I won the battleship game, ha.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

JeQggL-TQqO0Dtp5TtVXTw.text: We booked a table for a Birthday this week, but when we got there, the table was not available until 10-15 minutes later. At first they told us to wait, and that they will come to get us when the table was ready...As the lobby is nearly in-existant, we were a bit in the way, which finally lead our little group to wait outside. The staff did not really seem to care where we'd be waiting (nor did they told us about the downstairs bar where we could have waited...), and we had to go back to them regularly to check our table.Our table was located in the small room downstairs, nice and cosy, except for the walk the waitress took us through : walking in front of all services rooms and toilets to get to our table, while there were 2 others paths through the actual restaurant. Unfortunately, one of our table projector was half broken, giving us a very dim light that hurt your eyes more than anything compared to our friends'. I recon the experience is a novelty, but I hate the fact that it takes quite a while to figure out and to actually read the menu. The waitress only came 10 minutes after we sat down to explain how the tables were working...It is nice to change your table-cloth display, play little games, browse the menu, check the amount of your bill as you go; but it sort of cut your ties with your friends.  Once the novelty wears off, it is just like any other restaurant, with less service around...although it is nice to be able to order food without having to call someone.I had the glazed salmon, which was good, but not as new as I thought it would be, it tasted like in any other places. On the other hand, the hot-stone beef was quite good, and its display is a real delight. I loved the small fried praws; and some of us went for a hot plated- fish + rice (can't recall the name); which is mixed for you on the table and looked quite good. The price is quite high for the amount you get, even if it is tasty =( !Overall I'd say the food is good, but I wasn't fond of the overall concept and didn't have that much of a good experience with the service.They did not try to accomodate in any way when we where waiting, not even telling us where we could wait as a group of 6; as our table was broken, we told them it was a bit hard to actually read the menu, but they said they couldn't do anything about it (not even explain the menu apparently), the "call a waiter" function seems quite useless as nobody came when we needed someone..And the lady servicing us to sit us, take some of our coats ( one of my friends ask if they could take our coats, she took hers but did not bother asking anyone else for this), pay the bill,..was very unfriendly and unhelpful...

QJKo_vYtg17i59k7TRyejw.text: Theme restaurants or those with a gimmick are normally the kind of thing you should either run a mile from or only go in so long as you've brought your best sense of humour along too. As I'm usually up for an adventure with my sense of humour in tow, I've managed to spend entertaining and bizarre evenings in many an underground rainforest or full-on Austrian 'bierkeller'. It's a laugh, but usually, the food and drink hides itself away under the bright lights and mad surroundings. Inamo is the exception to this rather convoluted rule I have put in place. Yes, there is a big draw in its crazy tables of joy. Use the touch sensitive bit to navigate round the food and drink options, order it yourself, sit tight and wait for it to come. Even the waiting game is a little fun though, with battleships on the table and Chef Cam. And when the food does come... it's good, very good indeed. I had a speedy lunch menu (which may or may not have been its real name) - miso soup, cinnamon chicken, edamame, pickled aubergine (probably) and rice. And it was unexpectedly delicious. Great presentation and loads of food. The only downside to the process of creating a restaurant which absolves the staff of having to do any work is just that, that they do no work. The woman who served us was decidedly sulky and bored, and failed to see anything funny about my accidentally calling a taxi. It wasn't hard to do. Don't do what I did! Having said that though, I bet it happens all the time. Anyway, with an attidude like that, just as well the tables do the ordering.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

6zHGTYK0kKDHM_p1dH4KVQ.text: Eh. Inamo was ok. Would never go again and would not probably recommend it to anyone if I knew they were coming to London. Anything that wasn't meant to be served raw was overcooked and the food grade was pretty low across the board. My daughter was entertained by the novelty of the table projection system so if you do decide to eat here for that reason, the ribs and prawns in the small plate menu were palatable, and the black cod on the large plate menu was fairly good as well. Service was good. We didn't stay for dessert.

9ZOHzMWA0yTPb7sgyAJKEg.text: Funkiest place in London! Ordering is a pure pleasure on those touch screens. The food is delicious too, very nice and clean.Only trick is that it's too easy to order more and more dishes and the bill can get expensive!

4q7wcMsgHH35lOuWscLTCA.text: I've seen the future, brother, and it's murder. Mixed opinions from the Qypers, but I'd have to go with Chief_Patto's view, this place really is top draw! The interactive projection tables are SO MUCH FUN to use, and the image quality, even at lunchtime in daylight, is fantastic - you really can see what your food is going to look like. The feeling of sneakily ordering another beer without having to bother anyone, and drinking at your own pace is great, and when the bill comes, you can even see who's had what, ideal for parties of really tight people! Actually, not that ideal, since a bottle of lager is 4 quid, but a nice touch is that when they run out of something, it just disappears from the menu. No more, oh sorry, we haven't got any left moments - you won't EVEN KNOW they had it in the first place! Service was sadly not by T800's but by real people, and they were also frighteningly efficient, our bill arriving literally 10 seconds after we clicked send. You wouldn't want to eat here all the time, but it's definitely a taste of things to come. Oh, and the food is excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

AX_P3FFP_j1s6nK0LnR_fw.text: Interactive tables are very cool, where you can place orders, watch the chef, book a taxi and play battleship on the e-table. However the food is very underwhelming. Bit bland and very small portions for the price.Chinatown is not far away if you really want Oriental food.

v1HrExffSs606z_tMoWa3Q.text: Unlike others, I found the staff to be quick and helpful without being overly friendly.  I'm used to (American) staff that give suggestions, exaggerate the specials and have the check ready for you before you've ordered your dessert.  I enjoyed having control of my dining experience.  My his husband and I ordered aubergine, pak choi, hamachi, salmon, beef salad and grilled beef.  All were fantastic and will be ordered again. Fun idea, well executed menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

nx5tYk4NPhBtwRrdtB3SmA.text: 5 stars for the futuristic experience and ambience. 3 stars for the food itself though.Order from your table?? Actually ON your table.. sweet. Ambience was great - dimly lit, super modern, posh and filled with customers.Food (asian-inspired, but more thai than japanese):- Miso soup: £2.75, smaller than normal.- Futomaki sushi: not very authentic (way more rice than sushi filling).- Sashimi had stringy tendons:either it wasn't fresh or the cut wasn't very high quality.- Grilled green beans: delicious, but £5.50 for green beans?- Dessert, nothing spectacular. Black rice with mango seems unique but was too creamy and sweet for my liking.Seems everything is mini-sized here but the prices. Definitely must try  this place at least once though!
