GJkZOHCtBQGAQjB68hX3-g.text: Projector sushi!!!Well... an interactive screen is projected onto the table from above. You get to control it with a small touchpad on the table and order food from there. You can also play games on it and change the tablecloth pattern. Very funky.I took Frenchie on a date there as she loves sushi. We were both very pleased with the food (5 stars for the taste) and service was friendly. I had a quick look around and thought the place looked coo. For once the made bamboo decorations not look naf!Only setback was the price (about £75 including a bottle of sake).If you can afford it and are not too hungry, go for it.

4Z8Wk7a75Lq2BDCLqHDU7g.text: A coworker told me about the interactive tables at the restaurant, which is why I decided to have dinner here. The interactive tables were indeed very cool. You browse the menu by using the trackpad on the table. As you look at each dish, a projection of the dish appears on your plate so that you can see what it might look like in when it's served. You also order the food using the table interface. There's very little interaction with the waitstaff unless you ask for it, which I didn't mind at all. You can also use the table interface for playing games with the person at your table or watching the kitchen cam; both were fun ways to pass the time as we waited for our food.The food itself is actually pretty good. However, the dishes are expensive and the portions are small. Overall, the food wasn't delicious enough nor a good enough value for me to want to go back, but I really enjoyed the novelty of the interactive tables.

PHbMPHOIaM9OaVB_mZ3fyQ.text: Terrible service. Priced to the ceiling. An absolute disappointment. Walked out and got KFC. They gave us a 30% discount. Still too expensive for what you get and the staff!

ruWv2XIlLqLWRjnZQWczsw.text: Definitely worth checking out in terms of alternative technology but I have to say that it kind of already feels a tad dated.... not as advanced as I was anticipating. The tech is a bit clunky. They also forgot my order which isn't great.  Food was nice enough, nothing revolutionary though.I rate the bar downstairs though - it was quiet for a Saturday night in Soho - perfect spot if you want to escape the crowd and have a catch up with an old friend!

2LRYMTFBpIMfCjn93J7kpQ.text: The dining experience is fun: the table is interactive: you can order, play games, see a live kitchen camera. My sister and I played battle ship, changed the table "ambiance" all the time, etc... it's definitely a fun experience. I don't understand why they charge you a 10% automatic gratuity when you seldom interact with the staff. However, the restaurant is pretty pricey for the quality of food you are getting. Keeping in mind I come from Seattle where Sushi is phenomenal, its very difficult for me to rate sushi restaurants well when I have a high bar of comparison. We had the following: Soft Shell Crab Roll: not good, the crab was somewhat soggy and didn't have strong flavorSalmon Sashimi: not freshTuna Role: actually not badSeared Salmon Roll: decent, but again not freshGyoza: interesting spices and flavor, but you only get 3 pieces and pay around $7 usd. Overpriced for what you are getting. Malaysia noodles: this was actually really delicious. It was in a yellow curry, good spices, but overpriced at $18 usd

k1jX6b3YfaWgLgxToaPHAg.text: Dined here twice now. Once for my own sake after the original opening hype, second time for touristy reasons with family.Both times the lamb cutlets kicked my butt with deliciousness - but I think the menu's since changed! I'd safely say any red meat spiced with even an even vaguely szechuan mix is bound to be good. Excellent sushi too.Interactive tables and ordering really are just as fun as they sound! A definite must-try.

WEBxk7T1YqoLMekJtIwmlA.text: Fabulous technology! Great innovationSerious fun for kids to play games at the table and change the tablecloths via computer!Ordering online is fun but you need watch out for the total stacking up! We nominated one person to do the ordering so we could keep an eye on the bill! Food is somewhat pricey. Quality is fine but I think the prices reflect the high technology and uniquenessWould benefit from a few more dishes to choose from but brilliant fun and staff were all friendly and helpful.As with all my reviews, must comment on the washrooms! They do need some tlc....only loo roll to dry hands on and was no soap! The washrooms were rather neglected :(Overall a fun meal

1VLm02I2UTi8ydEv9fhb2A.text: pretty average food not sure about the ambiance slow but good service interesting concept (virtual menu)tip, if you are starving and want food in the next 20 min this is not for you go somewhere else, go here if you have plenty of time, plenty of patience and if you are looking for something different so a friend and i were in sake no hana having cocktails (if you haven't been there probably its time for you to go check it out)after a couple of drinks i said shall we go upstairs and have something to eat?looks like friend was feeling a bit adventurous and recommended this place inamo in soho i was never there so i googled it, it looked ok had a look to a couple of reviews seemed fine, so we were on our way, Bad choice next time i wont be listening to this so called friend!so we got there! first impressions- i wanted to kill this so called friend :/we sat and waiter explained the system theres a proyector and you use the table as your screen, you have to scroll and choose your food on the virtual menu, it basically feels like ordering a take away on your laptop!after 15m going trough the virtual menu i Couldn't Find what i wanted to eat i like wagyu, black cod, beef teriyaki, chicken yakitory, asparagus, dragon roll..... anyway 15 min is enough time, so i called the waiter and ask him can i have a normal menu? im sorry i cant find what i wanna eat, i dont have the patience to go through all of this i just wanna eat please' the manager came over to see what was happening i explained him and after that they brought me a proper menu i ordered still water, a mojito, black cod, chicken satay and some rolls we waited almost an hour to get some food.mojito didn't taste good at all i sent it backdry black cod chicken satay was not good plus the peanut sauce tasted like miso sauce?rolls should be warm or room temperature'! but these were cold like they have been sitting in the fridge for ages and the rice was undercook when the waiter came back for feedback i explained myself and why i didn't eat the food he looked at me surprised and apologised, at the end he took off a couple of things of the bill and the service charge and on top of that a 30% discount, the manager also came over and apologised, which i thought was a nice gesture and very good customer service sadly food let them down.

NAgsMpeTaotsUlLA9plCiA.text: Go in 35 minutes before they close. Tehy ask me if I have a reservation. Then the hostess telsl me kitchen is already closed. Don't be rude and waste my time by closing 35 minutes early.

436I7sjY0E56yZbbPV26yA.text: The food was nothing special as far as Asian cuisine goes. What you pay (too much in my opinion) for is the novelty of ordering via the admittedly cool projections on your table.  Not only can you order your food and drinks, but you also choose the ambience, request taxis, call your waiter, as well as challenge fellow diners to games.For food I had the satay chicken which was overwhelmed in soy and honey.  The gyoza was delicious but not anything that blew my mind, and finally I had the duck and pancakes which was on a par with my local take away but with a larger price tag.Service was friendly but we were left too often with used plates which took a while to be cleared. The service is limited though due to the fact that you order your own food.Worth a trip to try something new, but not for pretty standard Asian food.

_OuL7z1nLB1uZFMWZ7A4ZQ.text: The interactive menus are very cool and add a great touch, making it a fun and quirky dining experience. The staff are also lovely,  however the food is fairly average-good but average. Worth a visit for the whole experience but I probably wouldn't go back unless someone else was paying!

FLG5Io7B2tyMbjVPYoP8vQ.text: We ate here for lunch on a Saturday.  It is a fusion pan Asian / Japanese place -- some of the dishes have excellent Indian spices and chutney incorporated. The technology is fantastically cool and worked well (except the "kitchen cam" was down).  Basically, you order with a touchpad built into your table, with a screen that shines down to cover your table top.  Touching a dish, for instance, shows a picture of the dish on your plate.  You select what you want through the touchpad -- the kitchen cooks it and a live waiter/waitress delivers it to your table.One advantage of the system is that you can order incrementally, which is a dining style I personally really prefer.Kitchen and service, despite the restaurant being 2/3rds empty was surprisingly slow, but we were relaxed and not in a rush.The food was quite good.  The cooked dishes were more special than the sushi/sashimi.A la carte and drink prices are a bit high -- it's more special occasion or date pricing than a normal gig place.  They also have some set menus, which we did not try.In summary, if you're a tech geek and like Asian fusion like me, this place is 5 stars. If you're here mainly for the food, you'll probably feel it's over-priced.I have no affiliation with this restaurant nor (to the best of my knowledge) anyone who works there.

CdBU1wqc0_-H4wTebw0Xvw.text: Very cool place to try if you've never been- a unique experience. Everything is done from the table- ordering food, playing games, checking out where you're going next and even calling a cab. Futuristic table makes the experience, but I'd give the food 3.5 stars as it's mostly for the experience.

DZ0mCwEMlPwKjmNP5NCAXQ.text: Quick glance:+ novel, interactive tables and menus+ tasty food, but...- over priced- small portion sizes- disjointed customer serviceThe idea of ordering your food and drinks via a computer, projected onto the table, really excited my inner geek, but the novelty factor wears off quickly. First, the good: the whole table is covered in projected graphics and comes with two mouse pads on opposite end of the tables so that each diner can browse through the interactive menu and order separately. When each dish is selected, a picture of the food is projected onto the big round plate to whet one's appetite, although the resolution isn't superb so the photos are very fuzzy. While it was fun for the first few minutes working out how the fairly intuitive system works, I didn't like how you could only view one item of the menu at a time and navigation soon became quite tiresome. There are also other fun features such as maps of the restaurant, surrounding area (which supposedly highlights other fun places to go but it had little useful information), a live stream of the kitchen, and few computer games). Now, the bad: The food was fairly tasty, but it was both over priced and under portion, as in small portion sizes. For example, a small dish (kind of like a starter) of 5pcs. sushi was about £8, but each piece was so small that a child could eat it in one mouthful. I would have expected proper size sushi at that price... While the big dish, resembling a main, was slightly more generous, it was doubled the price of those offered by similar establishments in the area.For two of us, we had a starter and a main each plus a bottle of wine, and the bill came to just under £80. This is a fair price for most London restaurants, but the portion size has put me off. For the novelty factor and decent food, I would have rated it at 3-star, but I feel compelled to knock another star off for the disjointed service. We came for a 6:30pm evening service on a Monday and was promptly told we only have 1.5 hours, which we were happy with given it's the week of the London Olympic Games as well. When 8pm rolled around, the head waitress came over and said we have to vacate our table, despite the fact that around us were at least 3 empty tables with no one queuing, which I thought was not only rude but also made very little business sense. To top it off, as she left, another waitress came by and asked if we wanted another drink as she whisked away our empty wine bottle. We would have gladly stayed for an (overpriced) cocktail or digestif but decided to take our business elsewhere. All in all, Inamo is one of those places you visit to say you've been there and done that, but it's not worth a second visit after all that kerfuffle, unless they a) improve customer service, b) enhance the interactive system, and c) serve up proper portion of food (or at least make the price a little bit more realistically in line with other restaurants...).

MuGMLXgrrEj1jzbX7PSavQ.text: Technologically savvy but not savoury enough!Virtually ordering your food from the table is a fabulous idea. Technology in restaurants should get pipping out orders out in rapid time. Waiters should be able to concentrate on really explaining the food and chefs could focus on quality control. But this fabulous idea is more impressive than the reality of Inamo.In reality, this IT system needs some work. The poor waiters have to act like mini-IT technicians to work to intercept the virtual orders. The tables around us kept getting the wrong food, as did we. Still, the ordering system is a blast to use. Missing the crayons and coloring pages you got to entertain you as a kid? Draw with the mouse! Inamo would also be a great place for a date. Bored? Surf the menu! Can't decide what you want? Order everything in your basket and then decide right before checkout! You can't eat computers and this is a restaurant, so down the important stuff...Food-wise, Imano's fusion is solid but not particularly interesting. Inamo has a great idea, just needs some foodie and techie tweaking.

wUrfpj0dXSuQO3X0omyO0A.text: Inamo is uniquely distinguishable with its interactive tables. Had an amazing time here, great food and even better experience. If you've ever wanted to play games at dinner without the fear of a faux pas...this is the place for you.

HKzSx7vvNs4H5Kre5olFcg.text: Firstly, the techno side of things....it already feels dated. This technology has been around for a while and the fact it still promotes itself as pioneering is slightly wonky. However, it is fabulous if you have kids in tow. They can play around with the table tech and play games. My son has never been so enthusiastic in a restaurant situation.The food: mediocre. Well, the flavour was very mediocre. The presentation very good. But it lacked any punch whatsoever. Small portions - highly priced.The sushi rice seemed to have absolutely no sushinoko involved in its creation and therefore lacked flavour. We had to keep asking for soy sauce as no condiments are on the table.Once dishes are on the table the projected tech element dissolves into a farce as it cannot possibly be used after that.The "daily recipe"ice cream was rubbish. And it was incredulous that no one could tell me what the days flavour was! I had to try and work it out for myself until the waitress finally turned up with a scrap of paper telling me it was banana etc....terrible ice cream.Service was O.K. Friendly but rather aloof.Techno fad. Rather pointless and disappointing. But the kids will love it...

VP2wDpzJ_IgG3EhwnQkr9g.text: This place is not only very good, but also a fun and a nice experience. the restaurant is a sushi / dim-sum restaurant with nice food. the most insteresting part is however the menu that is projected on the table and each person can order just clicking on the items and adding them to their "cart".the service is very quick after you have ordered and the staff is nice. One warning to be made: I was there with a group of 6 people and we somehow lost track of how much we were ordering and we ended up with more food that initially thought. But everything was delicious so we ate it all!will come back

jyhg96w7QD6JI3QVzSYCSg.text: To be frank, I'm rather disappointed by this place, because I did have high expectations.The digital table ordering system is decidedly unusual - never seen anything like this. The menu is projected onto your table, and you can literally see what you're looking at ordering, sort of on your plate (although the sizing isn't really correct).It is an AYCE place, so that should've tempered my expectations, but given the hype surrounding it  (my cousins were certainly raving about it, and they've been to Japan and China, and I always thought they are finicky eaters (boy, was I wrong), I thought this place would be different.Well, it was different - the most expensive AYCE place I've ever been to (and probably will be), having spent nearly £50 to feed myself.Never again.

IinJ68ZagSnHARWfwAk39g.text: Bit lame, showing its age after 10 years. Food massively overpriced for Itsu quality dishes.

d2vwzFzIMNULnddgF2jDtA.text: All hype. Looking for a unique resto in London, I thought my computer-geek hubby would love Inamo. The table is basically a computer monitor where you order your food, can play games, change the colors, etc. The concept is cool, the food is not. Portions are tinier than tapas, more like bites. It's pricey and the quality isn't worth it. We had edamame and miso soup which you can't mess up. Then hubby had chicken satay skewers, and I, a seared salmon maki roll. My roll was insanely skinny and literally 4 petite bites and his were 3 tiny pieces. Both were also pretty bland and tasteless. We got some drinks to help the situation but just kept playing with the table. Even though it's fun to play with something while eating, I'd recommend skipping if you're actually hungry. 2 stars are for the service which was ok

FLODsvS3hy7Q-a8v1wbi-g.text: Decided to venture in here for my birthday lunch, I have heard so many good things about it, so had to try it!! Walked in and everything was so interactive, who needs waiters when you can order from a click of a button from your table and the order goes straight to the kitchen!.... And you can play games aganist your lunch date too, kept us both occupied. It was so easy to order the food, you can almost go a bit nuts and order too much, but I made sure we didnt. Ordered a few sushi dishes, tiger king prawns, korean chicken wings, chicken satay, kimchi, and edamame beans.The sushi was ok, nothing special, the tiger king prawns was another story, it was very fishy, the sauce on the outside was very tasty, but what a messy job to de-shell. Wings weren't anything special, although I did like the satay wings especially the chunky peanut sauce :) I usually like kimchi, but this was not good!! It made my mouth go all funny and when I do not like something, i make these weird facial expressions, that happened a lot at this place.As it was a quiet sunday, the food came out pretty quick, but there was no wow factor, it just seems like a mediocre place, I like the concept, its better than receiving table service, and there aren't no pesky waiters asking you if you're enjoying your food every 10 minutes, and you can only respond with a mouthful. However not a place I'd visit again....

vJuosuTlv9iqMoUdiptnOA.text: Interactive tables and Asian food? I was SO keen to try this place so decided to bring my friend last weekend. We booked and were therefore seated quickly and instantly shown how to order etc using the interactive tables.The whole concept is pretty cool - a projector which projects a photo of the dish on to your "plate" on the table so you can see what you are going to get along with a description before you order. Flicking through the cocktail menu then the food menu in this way was pretty fun and ordering from it was easy enough. Also being able to play games while waiting was fun however you can't deny it is gimicky and would expect the service and quality of food to compensate as the food is pretty pricey.The food was good however the portions were so small. 2 small sliders with a small bowl of fries was £17! And chicken satay skewers to start were nearly £10. I would come back here for the set menu which does make it good value for money however the experience my friend and I had was a hefty £80 bill for 2 small starters, 2 small mains and a few cocktails. Additionally they add service when half the work is done for them!

pkFiX8pFS4usY-HUTbUP0A.text: fancy place, great sushi. definitively a unique atmosphere

_nYogxmoHRMW16C_CRH6Sg.text: Wow wow wow loved it. Loved the interactive table, loved the games (ping pong, pairs, puzzle, battleships, pop balloon game), loved being able to change pattern on tablecloth (for a fee you can create your own table mat design has to be ordered 48 hrs before), loved watching chef cam and the food was great and full of flavour. Only downside is that the restaurant can get loud with all the people on other tables and I would like hot plates and everyone's food in your party might not turn up at same time.  Certain months / days they have entertainment ie magician.  I would deff go back there in future for a meal.

xI4bzhABDBcVk2nJfVpdYw.text: I was recommended this place by a friend, and was excited to try this interactive menu/dinning experience. First impressions of this place, is it looks very nice. Quite low lighting, but the tables are fully lit by a projector which allows them to be interactive. Each table has a iPad with the menu on, which allows you to pick your order without calling for a waitress. We had slight issues trying to remove items from our order, so needed to get a waitress in the end. My favourite part of this experience was being able to play games against each other, I really enjoyed my time here. I only have one fault and that is the tables are quite small so you can feel quite cramped if you have people on the tables next to you.

UAPWxT26tGJ4zQvHaoEM8w.text: So basically wanted to check this place out because of the hype around the interactive resturant vibe...Yes! The interactive tables are great, you can change the table cloth, order food/drinks, and can play games (battleship). This is the best thing about the resturant. However the service was not the best, as we had to wait over 20min  for our reservation. The menu is nothing grand, was expecting a lot more options. For example only had two soup and curry options. The portions were very small, I sear I had the skinnest sushi roll ever...lol It is a place to go just once for the experience, but I will not be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

HTASlnwcyTS9wmuvXd3lQg.text: I have heard SO MUCH about Inamo that my expectations were high. So when it came to picking a location for our anniversary, we thought it would be a good place to check out.So if you hadn't realised yet, Inamo is well known for having these interactive tables you can order from, and they serve Asian Fusion food. All good.How was it? Well sadly, it underperformed. Let me explain why.Service: For a place that isn't supposed to have any service, it managed to be a bit questionable. It took them 15min to turn on our table that would let us order, and the waiters constantly looked overwhelmed. Some were nice, some were less nice. Small minus point there.Food: So I get that you're paying a premium for the novelty, and although it was "good", it was not the level I would have expected it to be for the price we were paying. We had a few plates of Asian Tapas and Sushi to start off with: portions were relatively small, and it was overall a bit bland and un-exciting.For our bigger dishes we went for the crispy duck (a bit dry) and the marinated chicken - which was by far the best dish of the evening. We chose sorbet for desert, but as a consistent theme, they weren't amazing.Technology: Interesting concept that took me back to Japan where ordering on a tablet is relatively common. However - and don't call me a spoil sport - I found the technology a bit out-dated, it would have been amazing 3-5 years ago, but today it kind of feels a bit gimmicky. My touchpad wasn't working properly and would add stuff in my orders list without me selecting them - which made me very pretty frustrated. The few games that were on there were a fun entertainment though, had fun with those.So in short: It was a fun experience, I'm happy we went regardless. But probably wouldn't go again.

QR8DjYpA83nubc4ev7B5DA.text: I liked this place and enjoyed the meal but I felt it was a bit overpriced. Maybe we were paying for technology? They have interactive tables so you barely have waiter contact...you order your stuff yourself and hit send. The food was tasty and fresh but portions were super small. Miso soup was very good, crispy silken tofu was 4 minuscule blocks of tofu for 7 pounds.dim sum was 3 little pieces...again good but not great.

pLKSDKt9kWMi7eTCrLSYdQ.text: The projector menu is really cool, particularly for me since I study behavioral sciences. My friends had a lot of fun tinkering around with the games and backdrops. HOWEVER - I noticed something interesting during our meal. Normally, we are a group that's very good about not texting at the table and trying to engage each other in conversation. We put away our phones or turn them screen-down when we're eating. But because there was technology already at the table, it almost felt like we had license to use our phones, partly to document everything, but also because we were already disengaged from conversation by the colorful lights and images.The food itself is really mediocre. There isn't a great selection, and the things that are available are vague combinations of Asian fusion dishes that taste too bland to be identified as any kind of authentic regional cuisine. The portions are really tiny for what you pay. On top of that, I will credit the concept creator for this restaurant for the brilliant idea to make ordering so easy that we just kept ordering more and more food, oblivious to the price since we put in many individual, repeated orders rather than ordering all at once. My bill came to over £30 and I was still kind of hungry at the end.It's kind of a cool place to check out once, but I probably won't be going back until they make significant improvements to their cuisine.

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. Tuna sushi roll
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. Projection screen ordering

ytfEwd8ht8FII3W1-4TT8A.text: I went to this restaurant mainly because I heard about the interactive tables and not really for the food and I didn't get disappointed.You can choose the pattern of the table, play games such as battleship which is loads of fun and order your food after you have seen what it's gonna look like on your plate.I guess this would be the perfect place for a first date, just in case the conversation shouldn't flow as expected you could always play a game.The food was also really good, I had the Malaysian Noodles which were really tasty but there were way too many mushrooms in there. My friend had the salmon which was absolutely delicious! The desserts are amazing too but really pricey for the size of what you get!There are some negative points as well: the price which is too high and that they kicked us out after exactly 90 min! We booked the table in advance so you could expect to stay there a bit longer right?I'd go there again but only for a special occasion when I am ready to spend a lot of money...

4dt1-5pyNgQtpM2tvmXRsg.text: Fun idea but horrible dinner. The sushi was average and tiny, they half portions to save money, but the bill is pricey. The service was poor, we had to wait a lot for our food and the sushi arrived with no soy sauce, which we only got 10 minutes late. The Air con was the worse part, it was so cold we couldn't relax. We asked twice to turn it down but nothing changed. Tables are packed one next to the other, no privacy, and the place was really noisy, not a good spot for chatting. Worse part: I came out still hungry.

5t9dt0jmIaw2bIr2fLzEKQ.text: We came here based on a recommendation by a friend who had been Inamo's other restaurant at St. James.It is a fun concept.  The interactive tables where you press a button to see the menu and order your food is a quirky addition to a meal with friends.  The waiter service was good too though and our waiter was very attentive at all times.The food itself was ok.  I confess I was feeling really tired and probably not in the best frame of mind and my friends thought it was fantastic.  We ordered a selection of items from the Asian tapas and lnamo classic and the salads and nibbles menus, including Seafood Gyoza which was nice and flavoursome, the Kakiage (tempura vegetables) which were my favourite item on the menu, the Korean glazed pig cheeks which had a surprising kick to them and were very generous in size, crispy baby prawns which I found a bit meh but my friend loved so much she ordered a second helping, spicy aubergine which was lovely and chicken satay which to me didn't actually taste like chicken.My main problem though was the price.  This is not a cheap night out.  The bill came to over £50 a head and I did not feel the food was good enough at that price.  However my other two friends thought it was worth it so you probably need to go and make up your own mind.  Either way it was an interesting experience.  I'm just not sure I would be rushing back.

cq-RyKhVWtyWkazVeJEKjA.text: A friend from NYC came to town and said she's been to inamo and really wanted to go back. i made the Soho reservation since she hadn't been to that area yet.I used toptable. When i tried to change it from 2 to 3 people five minutes after booking, it said they could not accommodate. Like a reasonable person, I called. No answer. I tried a few times. Still no answer. When I did arrive with a 3rd, they could not accommodate. At least my friend was understanding. We were sat and it took a while for someone to come explain how to order to us.Plus side:-The ordering on the table is really cool. I liked that the food options would appear from the projector on the plate in front of you. We also changed our 'tablecloth' for each course.-Had a £15 bottle of wine. (it was decent)-Served the £15 two course set menu all night (even though toptable said only until 7)-The man who brought our bill was italian. And friendly. Why it's a 2:-I made a joke with the man showing us how to use the table that it discriminates against Lefties (mouse is built into table ONLY on the right side). Mind you I said this with a smile. He did not recognize the semi joke and responded in such a manner - but not one with any sincerity or levity. -Spicy Eggplant as the 'small.' So this was a lot. But, it was pretty oily and the skin not crispy enough.-Yuzu sauce on the salmon. While I liked the flavor, sort of overwhelming. Could they have halved the amount to give some flavor but not engulf?Maybe they couldn't have controlled the various fruit flies that hung around our meal. But maybe they could have. Really annoying.I will say, my friend's duck pancakes looked wonderful. Her seared salmon sushi starter was ok - not too big.Cool concept but the food didn't match up.

NFkZlgxIOvoU8l2qR003Vg.text: The technology is pretty cool, but the food is  rather mediocre. I was here for lunch and had the bento box, (and the bento was the only available main dish choice?? )I don't know about dinner but the lunch menu doesn't have much to offer...

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom

SuvnZWri8RnVp1DESYif2Q.text: Well what can I say, it's probably the start of way restaurants are going in an all futuristic way! this place is amazing and probably one of my best places to to eat recently!. Upon arrival you are taken to your table and the waiter explains how to order your drinks and food, as you can see in my pictures the tables have the information projected down to the table from above and controlled with a built in mouse, you choose your items and send to the kitchen, also while your order is being cooked you can play games (even 2 player games like Battleships with the person opposite you) also there's a Kitchen Camera that shows the live feed so you can see the chefs preparing the meals in the Kitchen, you can even plan your journey home or even order a cab from the table. The food tastes amazing, my favourite dish being the Scallops, one good thing about this place is if you are in a party of 3 or more you can see your individual amount on your table and the overall group amount, only one criticism I would say is that we sat downstairs near the toilets/kitchen entrance and felt a bit like we was in the overflow bargain basement as all the ambience I felt was upstairs in the main area, so if you do go, ask for a table upstairs, but to finish my review the whole concept of this restaurant is a big step into the future and I would go back from time to time to experience new dishes!

photos.caption: Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. Korean Lamb with Kimchi
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. Scallops
Photo of Inamo - London, United Kingdom. Virtual Kitchen Cam, see how your foods coming along!

irqwoLhBQW5k0O2iulRtgw.text: Even though I had full control of my service with the projector screens , the service by actual waiters was really good-they were very attentive. I felt like a child going into here. Yes, it is intimate sort of but I loved playing around on the projector and watching the chef cook! And there's lots of games to okay with friends too! The good was great, not a big portion for the price but that's expected with the type of restaurant it is. Will definitely recommend and go again!

y_HsLreumOI2ZDTBxBE07A.text: Definitely a very interesting experience  the interactive menus probably were the main attraction. The food was good and in comparison to the quality, probably fair priced, too, although I was expecting something more quirky. However, the seating plan was somewhat off-putting  all diners were cramped together in small rooms (or at least we were) which made me uncomfortable. While I would recommend it experience-wise with the menu set-ups, I wouldn't go back there myself as the food was just not amazing enough to return.

lwFfY3bAdDKQMsDs_1axhQ.text: Great concept, delicious food and overall fun time!

In8Yp5VLe2Whp3psf_92aQ.text: Asian fusion is the headline but that doesn't do it justice. The food here was first class. As far as I was concerned I was prepared to accept something average because what caught my eye was the fancy gadgetry at Inamo. The projected table displays create a uniquely chilled ambiance at this place as well as taking all the hassle out of waiting to be serverd. I won't try to repeat what they describe on their own website but basically you can change the background 'skin' on your table at your leisure. Sounds like nothing much but the range of images from rain forest to views of space really set a nice tone for the meal. Then you just order everything from the interactive menu at each persons place. Including another round of beer which arrives within 2 mins! Good food and funky technology, perfectly combined.

I-wpFRTr7jSpWr_QKpj74Q.text: Food (I had the standard bento) was ok, but not especially delicious. Prices were fair given its central London location and the general OK quality of the food. The whole 'gimmick' is their interactive ordering system. Now that I have tried it out and seen the ordering system (which was pretty cool), I wouldn't go back again. General verdict is that it is cool to try out and see what the fuss is about, but after you have seen it, you won't be tempted to go back again.

0quCSGdovwX_uagNaaGJWg.text: This has 5 stars for one reason, I've been twice, and the food and service standards are still just as high as the last time. I'm not one for letting novelty overshadow the food, but in this case, they are perfectly paired. I found out about the place in an American based technology blog that picks up geeky bits and pieces, and booked it straight away. The best things that you are in control of, the ambience of your own table, and ordering cocktails at the flick of a finger. The worst,.. the price bracket means that this won't be a regular local haunt for me, but for occasions it was perfect. (now I just need to justify some occasions to the Minister of War and Finance...). My final words,.. Lychee Martini

4i427tmfxDgavJZUzs77cg.text: so i finally got to go here. i gotta say the reason i went was all to do with the whole interactive table projection thing.it was great having the control over your order, you can order in batches say if you wanted to make sure your starters came first.also, i like to just have the menu on hand while im eating and you can enter the menu at anytime the categories, i think were, smaller dished, larger set menus and drinks and desserts. Its is not the greatest quality of projection, infact its quire shabby, theres no excuse as its meant to be the centrepiece of the restaurant, invest in decent projectors guys! and my touchpad had some rice stuck in it - well informed design???Extras in the interactive system were great, games, call the waiter / ess over and view the bill so far!!! i wonder how much of a pain it is to incorporate one of those 'spilt the bill calculators into the system since they are so ubiqtous - well on the iphone it is.Noteworthy dishes in our order were the Kailan (side) and the thai red curry. I ordered peppermint tea which was damn good peppermint tea as it happens, i think it was called 'whole leave peppermint tea' i had a tripple choclate dessert which i thought was really overpriced!Do make reservations or like me you will end up waiting for and hour and a half - if youre lucky!

0uxhtUjHQmYoZx2KQ4LbgA.text: We came to Inamo to celebrate the birthday of a friend ... and it turned out to be a birthday party with a difference.It started off on a bad note. We came 15 mins before time and so were asked to wait. The five of us went outside and were chatting. When we went back in 10 mins later (still before our reservation time), we were told that they couldn't find us and so had given our table to some other group. This was really uncalled for. However they subsequently arranged seats for us very soon. Everybody has talked about the futuristic computerized table. You can see the dishes in scale as if they were set in front of you. You can order from there, play games, look at maps, check your bill, and as my friend (the birthday boy ) did, set a timer to automatically change the table cloth pattern every 2 mins :)The food was good, but not exceptional. I liked the starters, wild boar and oyster. I had taken a set menu for the main course. With sushi, prime ribs and edamame, it really was a fusion menu. Tasted pretty good and we were all stuffed by the time we finished.Note that unlike most Asian places, they do not serve rice with their thai curries ... it has to be ordered separately.Inamo didn't serve birthday cakes, but they allowed us to get our own and cut it there :) ... half an extra star to them for this.Overall the food was more like 3 star, but its definitely worth a visit for its distinctive ambience.

SQiL4rol0UsdlkObZApe1w.text: I think I'm only adding to the general warmth towards Inamo; yes it's a novelty, and yes the novelty just about wears off somewhere between eating your meal and ordering the bill - but the food is good enough to raise the admittedly geeky table interaction above pure tokenism. I found prices to be average (maybe not if you like exploring the more tucked away & traditional East Asian eateries in Soho), but it doesn't break the bank - especially if you take advantage of the lunchtime deals (via Toptable and and its ilk). A really fun experience, and I imagine a great, quick place to take clients and friends alike.

QqKLj5z75AHIuVwiAv8KMg.text: Decent sushi venue with quality cocktails...however the main selling point of this place is the interactive dining tables. Perfect for group eating or situations when you don't want to speak much with the people you are dining with...not that I would want to do that.

OsQR9OsaNoYAOFKn7_oHJQ.text: I am rating this restaurant with one star not because of the food, but because of the totally uncourteous way I was treated there. Having arrived into London that morning, we were tired and jet lagged and tried to eat at the inamo down the street in St James but they were closed for a private party so they pointed us to their other branch in Soho. When we got there, we were told they couldn't seat us and we needed to wait an hour at least for the next table. There were empty tables in the restaurant and we pleaded with them to make an effort to accommodate us earlier since we were tired and hungry. Not only did the manager turn us back rudely, she didn't seem to care at all when I said that their attitude cost them loyal customers. I am writing this review to remind everyone reading it that courtesy and customer service are as important as food when rating a restaurant. This one was a clear disappointment due to the pretentious attitude of the manager.

OM8DFsCiCzg4a3RcAFSKnQ.text: Girlfriend and I went for lunch on 18th Feb 2010, food was excellent very fresh and high quality. We ordered one large and three small dishes which was perfect, def recommend the Vietnamese Spring Rolls. In addition to the food and décor the interactive ordering from the tables, creating your own ambience, playing Battleships etc add to the whole place being one of the best in London I have been to. Worth noting they have a great room at the back available for private hire for approx 20 people There is also a bar downstairs.

fJRtdtkSQrg-_0-A3-yEsw.text: The entertainment does not withstand the lack of service at Inamo. Having eaten there on a friday night might have been the first mistake, but not receiving the human support that is needed in a restaurant is more then disappointing. A waiting time of 60 min in a half full restaurant was one of the things that went wrong from the beginning on. Not knowing what the food is tasting like, as no waiter was describing it was another. Being surprised about the spiciness of the food, even so that it was not advertised as such, another. Having to justify why I did not like the food, and why, just another point. Being treating with no respect after complaining of the lack of support/information about the state of the flawed meal. another. Therefore I would advice anybody if there want to go there for the Interactive tables. Go there but do go further then any starters. This is the review of the London out Mains, however, suffered from inflated prices and miniature portions. The hot stone rib eye was laughable  a munchkin-sized sponge of beef atop a soap-sized 'hot' plate that didn't actually manage to 'cook the beef to [our] liking'  fortunately, we do like our steak still mooing, and the kitchen has since admitted to the stone not working as well as they'd hoped. Marinated quail (singular) was finger-licking good, though poorly matched with plum wine-poached nashi pear that managed to emulate the sickly taste of cotton candy. An evening that had started on a high note with amusement and accomplished starters ended up leaving us unsated and unsatisfied, pining for some more substantial grub in a nearby Soho greasy spoon.

XRoZxF98U7hlpH2pEmOjhA.text: Really good concept - certainly something to keep you entertained if you go with bad company (which luckily wasn't my case!) Starters poor, Mains really good and puddings OUT OF THIS WORLD!! Really good value for money - bit cheeky with the old service though seen as how you do half the work your self!!

H5K2ckIEDzNtLPMuimphUQ.text: ambiance and experience was cool having the table as a big ipad. other than that the food's pretty shite. don't order anything that's raw (thus supposed to be cold) bc it'll come out nice and warm (nothing nastier than warm sashimi). everything else was doused in a TON of sauce. even the "salad". bleehhh

yVHrOHxeGYGWQDEAIfdxhA.text: Had a lovely time  food was delish and table was fun. Unlike some other restaurants with a gimmick  we would def go back to try more things on the menu. Loved the ice cream. Everyone in the restaurant was smiling too and we ended up chatting to the people next door  they've created a really good vide with the music and table decorations. Not the cheapest but me and himself walked out happy bunnies.

yxuo2s-OIljFY5hgfb9CQg.text: Been to this place twice and loved it both times. The USP of this restaurant (if you haven't already worked it out from the other reviews) is that the menu is projected on to your table and you select your food from the list using a small 'mouse pad type thing' i.e. the waiting staff do not take your order. each time you 'point' to a dish on the list a picture of it is projected on to your 'plate' (and round white pastic disc on the table!) which helps with deciding. You can order your drinks in the same way, which is good because they arrive at the table within 2 mins of ordering and you don't have to wait to be asked. Once you have ordered your food you can 'play around' with the menu whilst you wait. They have games such as battleships which you can play against your fellow diners, or you can watch the chef prepare your food on the kitchen webcam. You can also change your 'tablecloth' to project different patterns and colours onto your table. When you are all done you simply click 'bring me the bill' and you are good to go. As far as the food goes, the portions were not huge but the food was really good, strong flavours and very good quality. Having said that, it was very priceyfor what we got - I think you are paying for the novelty of the place. This is not somewhere you want want to go on a regular basis, but a good choice to take someone who has never been to Inamo before, will certainly wow and amuse them!

Ij70gdFzdmsFaw3u9vw5hg.text: How refreshing to find somewhere that has a unique selling point (its technology) and is therefore somewhat of a gimmicky restaurant, yet serves such great food. Love it. Its small, intimate (you really must make a reservation), fun to order and play games with your dinner partner and when the food arrives, its fabulous ! Loved the blackened cod and seared scallops. Only gripe was that like Wagamama, the food all kind of comes together, so if you want to eat in traditional courses, order it as you go along, rather than all at once like you would with a real waitress.

o-jBYQ44QclfZXPrWvA42Q.text: Pretty damn swish place - has a really cool interactive ordering system and the food is also high quality. Its a bit pricey, but worth a visit for a new experience.
